paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Typhlops (Onychocephalus) schinzi Boettger, 1887a: 154
, pl. 5, figs. 1–2. Type locality: “Noi Xas unweit Ghanze in der Nord-Kalayari, Südweat-Afrikas” [= between Aus and Keetmanshoop, Great Namaqualand, Noixas, Ghansi District, W. Kalahari, Botswana ] (type locality restriction by
Mertens, 1971: 75
) ( 21.567°S , 21.783°E , elevation 1155 m ), holotype SMF 16665 (formerly SMF 7047, 1A), collected by H. Schinz, 1884–1885;
Mertens, 1922: 178
,
1967: 88
.

Typhlops schinzii —
FitzSimons, V., 1962: 70, fig. 8, col. pl. III, 1966a: 38;
Isemonger, 1968: 85
,
1983: 88
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Snout prominent, strongly hooked, with a sharp cutting edge extending back to the nostrils, which are directed more or less laterally; rostral large, oviform, but not reaching the level of the eyes, ventrally about half the width of the head at the level of the nostrils; frontal hexagonal; supraocular large, transverse, its lateral apex between preocular and ocular; eye distinct towards anterior edge of ocular; nasal in contact with first and second labial, nasal suture arising from first. SIP T-II (N2, P, O, O), rarely T-X (on the left side of the holotype — Boettger, 1887a , pl. 5, fig. 1c). MSR 22–26 (mean 24.4, n = 17); MD 413–538 (mean 455.1, n = 14); vertebrae 217–272 (mean 236.8, n = 13); MD/V ratio 1.87–1.99 (mean = 1.92, n = 13); L/D ratio 34–64 (mean 45.9, n = 9). Pinkish to yellowish above, usually speckled with blackish to reddish brown, sometimes forming irregular crossbands, which may be confluent; uniform below. Largest specimen ( CM 119342 —Luderitz, Namibia ) has a total length of 293 mm .
Distribution. From northwestern Namibia south to the Northern Cape Province of South Africa and the extreme west of Botswana near Ghanzi , 690–1310 m .
